PHOENIX, AZ 85017

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At time of inspection, the licensee stated that there was no written program of veterinary care available for review. The
licensee identified veterinarian A as their attending veterinarian and stated it had been "a couple years" since their last
site visit. After the inspection and exit briefing, the licensee emailed the inspector and identified the intended future
"primary care doctor" as veterinarian B. The inspector called veterinarian A, who confirmed they were the attending
veterinarian of the licensee and it had been "several years" since their site visit of the facility. Failure to maintain a written
program of veterinary care with a part-time attending veterinarian impedes the ability of APHIS Officials to carry out their
duties in assessing welfare of animals and ensuring the licensee is giving appropriate authority to the attending
veterinarian. Each exhibitor shall have an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements who shall provide adequate
veterinary care to its animals in compliance with all components of 2.40. In the case of a part-time attending veterinarian,
the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises
of the exhibitor.
Correct by 17 April 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At time of inspection, the licensee stated that the attending veterinarian had reviewed and approved the plan during their
site visit a few years prior. The inspector called the attending veterinarian to discuss the plan and the veterinarian could
not recall reviewing the plan and could not confirm approving it. Failure to develop, document and follow an environment
enhancement plan for nonhuman primates as directed by the attending veterinarian may result in substandard care of the
animals. Exhibitors must develop, document and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to
promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates as directed by the attending veterinarian.
Correct by 17 April 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At time of inspection, the licensee stated that there was no written program of veterinary care available for review. The 
licensee identified veterinarian A as their attending veterinarian and stated it had been "a couple years" since their last 
site visit. After the inspection and exit briefing, the licensee emailed the inspector and identified the intended future 
"primary care doctor" as veterinarian B. The inspector called veterinarian A, who confirmed they were the attending 
veterinarian of the licensee and it had been "several years" since their site visit of the facility. Failure to maintain a written 
program of veterinary care with a part-time attending veterinarian impedes the ability of APHIS Officials to carry out their 
duties in assessing welfare of animals and ensuring the licensee is giving appropriate authority to the attending 
veterinarian. Each exhibitor shall have an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements who shall provide adequate 
veterinary care to its animals in compliance with all components of 2.40. In the case of a part-time attending veterinarian, 
the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises 
of the exhibitor.  
Correct by 17 April 2024. 
3.81 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At time of inspection, the licensee stated that the attending veterinarian had reviewed and approved the plan during their 
site visit a few years prior. The inspector called the attending veterinarian to discuss the plan and the veterinarian could 
not recall reviewing the plan and could not confirm approving it. Failure to develop, document and follow an environment 
enhancement plan for nonhuman primates as directed by the attending veterinarian may result in substandard care of the 
animals. Exhibitors must develop, document and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to 
promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates as directed by the attending veterinarian. 
Correct by 17 April 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
